Has anyone run into this issue? Was testing something on our robot and realized that the radio power module was malfunctioning and melted. Didnâ€™t trip any breakers and students claimed that power pins werenâ€™t hot to the touch.

Was it close to any other components that could have gotten hot? That board looks weirdly clean for a board hot enough to melt plastic. Not saying its not the RPM, it just is interesting.

Was it plugged into a 40amp breaker? What guage wire were you using on it? If you feel the ground wire on it while on does it feel hot? That will show resistance in your loop.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":43,"updated_at":"2023-02-10T06:46:45.150Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":692,"readers_count":691,"score":153.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":426326,"topic_slug":"melted-rev-radio-power-module","display_username":"jack greer","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51801,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/melted-rev-radio-power-module/426326/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3142993,"name":"Carlos Gross Jones","username":"CarlosGJ","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/carlosgj/{size}/131747_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-10T06:49:31.417Z","cooked":"

Well, thatâ€™s exciting!

Naturally, Rev will ask you to send them the unit, so that they can do proper analysis. But as long as weâ€™re here, this arouses my curiosity.

Generally, in a power supply circuit, one expects a switching element to overheat in the event of overload, or maybe a filter in certain topologies; usually this means a FET, or occasionally a small coil.

In this case, you have obvious melting on the area of the case farthest from any components. U2 there is the obvious candidate, but itâ€™s kinda centerline on the PWA, and the melting is noticeably on one side. Okay, sure, if the module was mounted vertically, convection could play a part, but Iâ€™d still expect to see a hotspot on the bottom of the case near U2, if that were the culprit.

I feel like youâ€™d almost need a internal trace along the side of the PWB, acting as a very localized heating element, to get this kind of signature.

kellyissure:

Was testing something on our robot and realized that the radio power module was malfunctioning and melted.

Smalls:

compressor that was off for the whole day

Do you know for certain that the compressor was never run with the RPM nearby on this machine (at any point in itâ€™s lifetime)? Even though you just noticed it then, perhaps it had been like that for a little while.

Sounding (and looking) a lot like the RPM accidently touched the hot compressor at some point, causing the melting.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":43,"updated_at":"2023-02-10T14:46:43.187Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":2,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":533,"readers_count":532,"score":151.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":426326,"topic_slug":"melted-rev-radio-power-module","display_username":"Brian Wagg","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":19532,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Brian Wagg"},"post_url":"/t/melted-rev-radio-power-module/426326/11","custom_user_title":"Brian Wagg","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3143098,"name":"Cole Shumaker","username":"c.shu","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/c.shu/{size}/136963_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-10T14:50:13.631Z","cooked":"

Might be a silly question, but was someone using a heat gun nearby to bend Lexan or heat shrink some wires? It could be melted from an external source.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":43,"updated_at":"2023-02-10T14:50:13.631Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":500,"readers_count":499,"score":165.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":426326,"topic_slug":"melted-rev-radio-power-module","display_username":"Cole Shumaker","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":6}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":17731,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"9237 - Lead Mechanical Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/melted-rev-radio-power-module/426326/12","custom_user_title":"9237 - Lead Mechanical Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3143130,"name":"Zach Brown","username":"21brownz","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/21brownz/{size}/261799_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-10T16:03:31.484Z","cooked":"
CarlosGJ:

Generally, in a power supply circuit, one expects a switching element to overheat in the event of overload, or maybe a filter in certain topologies; usually this means a FET, or occasionally a small coil.

In this case, the size of that switching FET vs the inductor tells me the inductor would saturate and get toasty before the FET gets so upset it radiates enough heat to melt plastic. I find it very hard to believe the melting is due to anything on this board, especially given breakers didnâ€™t trip and the power pins werenâ€™t hot.

This caught my attention because we too lost comms randomly last night and we use the RPM.

The wifi showed up, but said we were unable to connect to it.

How the event went:

  • Enabled
  • Programmer drove a bit to make sure nothing seemed off
  • Disabled (did not turn off or change locations)
  • Handed off to the driver for some practice when they got there
  • Lost comms
  • Tried a hard reset (waited a few minutes)
  • Noticed the wifi was there but would not allow connection
  • Left on while looking over the wires (no issue found there)
  • Connected
  • Practiced
